div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 4 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Service Maritime Roumain
div.p: 16 Rue Sesostris 16

Par suite de la quarantaine de 48 houres imposée par la Turquie aux provenances d'Egypte les paquebots-poste du Service Maritime Roumain quitteront Alexandrie chaque quinzaine le Mercredi à 4 heures de l'après midi. Au cas où cette quarantaine serait réduite à 24 heures seulement les départs auront lieu le Jeudi à 4 p.m.
Alexandrie, le 25 Juin 1907.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.

div.head: TRAFFIC IN TITLES.
div.p: "The exposure of abuses committed by one's friends is a perilous, if a pleasant, task ; and Mr. H. C. Lea bids fair to be the best-hated man in the House of Commons," writes the "Saturday Review." "But it is not the business of reformers, any more than of the primitive Christians, to be agreeable, and we applaud the member for East St. Pancras, with certain reservations.

"For many years past the "Saturday Review" has denounced the shameful selling by both political parties of the highest honours in the Sovereign's gift. What is called, in the grave and respectful language of our Constitution, the 'fountain of honour' had become, under successive political turn cocks, a dirty spray of dishonour, and it was high time that public attention should be called to the matter. With the luckless Scottish knight who was useful te the Prime Minister at elections, and who was director of a company that supplied the Navy with a defective rudder, we need not concern ourselves. He had done more to deserve a
title than many who have received peerages and he has served Mr. Lea as a .peg on which to hang a very important Constitutional question."

"For with all respect to Mr. Speaker Lowther, we do not for a moment admit that the Prime Minister is not responsible to Parliament for the advice which he gives the Sovereign in the matter of honours and rewards. The Prime Minister is responsible to Parliament for everything which he does and says. It is true that the granting of titles is theoretically the peculiar privilege of the Crown, and that the Sovereign is not bound to ask, nor the Prime Minister to give, advice on that subject. But if the Prime Minister does ad vise the Sovereign to grant a title, he is clearly responsible for his a/lvicc to both Houses of Parliament. We do not know why the House of Lords, for its own protection, has not before now called upon -the Prime Minister to explain his advice to the King in the matter of peerages.

"What we strongly object to is the replenishing of party funds by the sale of peerages to the unworthy. Knighthoods and baronetcies do not so much matter ; they are mete ornaments, like a riband. But a peerage is a political status, conferring amongst other trifles the right of making or hindering laws."

The "Nation" thinks that the cause of democracy suffers by the persistence of methods which do not belong to it, and must injure ami retard it. "It cannot make either for Radicalism or for public morals that there should be two elements in the honour lists, the title which is freely bestowed, and can be openly defended, and the title which is the result of obscure agreements or understandings between a rich man and his party's Whips. We may indeed well believe that Liberal statesmen pray to be delivered from a system which so vitally weakens their intellectual appeal, and would gladly substitute for it the open party fund, subscribed for by the mass of Liberals all over the country. This is in the main the financial basis of the Independent Labour Party and the Nationalist Party. Many think that if people desire reform they should pay for propagating it; just as if they desire Socialism, or Nationalism, or one form ' of religious activity in preference to another. This would be an advance on the present custom of quietly accepting help from rich men and allowing them to suppose that they will be paid with a social reward, of more or less distinction. But it is not a full solution of the difficulty. That can only come through a reform on which all democratic sections are united, the payment of members ami of election expenses "

"If Liberalism is what it professes to lie, it will endeavour so te remodel the political system that the party leader of the future will have no use for either the snob or the monopolist," declares thq "Freeman's Journal."

Mr. H. C. Lea, M.P., who provoked the discussion of this matter, says that at an early date he will suggest the appointment of a committee of twenty-one members to investigate and make public an account of the working of party funds for the last few years.

div.head: Tho Vitriol Case.
div.p: Dr. Kassab, deputed by the Belgium Consul at Cairo to consider the state and wounds of A Goldschmidt, has made his report. The eye is safe, but the wound will leave an indelible mark caused by the burns. The examination into the case continues. The Chancellor of the Consulate visited yesterday morning the prison where Vittorine Heureux is detained, in order to communicate to her the result of the evidence which has l>een taken. During his visit Vittorine Heureux was attacked with hysterical convulsions, and remained in this -tate for two hours. She afterwards heard the evidence and confirmed it. The case will prob ably come Wore the Consulate tribunal on Munday on Tuesday next.

div.head: The Influence of Hashish.
div.p: On Saturday last while passing through rue El Guirani, Alexandria, a woman heard loud cries. Looking up she perceived that a young woman was making heroic efforts on the balcony of the third storey of a hon<c to detach herself from the arms of an infuriated man, who was evidently living to throw her into the street A native ♦ i\ant wa> seen to l*e holding his mistress .•oid it was undoubtedly owing to his efforts that the woman was not precipitated to • < rtain death. Eventually neighbours inter viirid and rescued the unhappy woman from the clutches of the husband, but the man persisted in demanding that she should leave the house with her two children, one of them only 2 years old. Subsequent inquiry revealed that this deplorable incident was the result of a domestic quarrel, owing to the wife attending the funeral ceremony of one of her relatives, in defiance of her husband's wishes. It transpired that the man was an Israelite addicted to hashish, and who at the time of the quarrel was under its influence. Through his persistence the woman was finally ejected from the house and passed the rest of the night on the -fairs, the neighbours not daring to take ler in owing to the fury of the man.

div.head: BRITAIN AND EGYPT.

SIR E. GERY"S PEONOUNCEMENT.
div.p: London, Friday.

Sir Edward Grey speaking in the House of Commons said that he did not wish to discourage the ideal of self-government, but he thought it necessary to utter a warning that the premature establishment of self-government would not lead to the benefit of the lower classes in such a community as that of Egypt.

div.head: FINANCIAL ADVISERSHIP.
div.p: A corresponding writing from Cairo under the signature of "Quidnunc" says :—

The e Financial Advisership is the most important appointment in the Egyptian Government for it is, as Lord Milner said, "the corner stone of English influence inside the Egyptian Administration." Sir Vincent Corbett has sent in his resignation and will return to the Diplomatic Service. He will probably obtain a good position as he has some influence in the Foreign Office. He is the brother-in-law of Sir Charles Hardinge, the British Ambassador at Saint Petersburg and formerly Assistant Under Secretary for Foreign A flairs, which position he left to become Am bassador in 1901 ami was succeeded by Sir Eldon Gorst. Sir Vincent Corbetts other brother in law is Viscount Chelsea, Lord

Cadogan's eldest son. This resignation has naturally given rise to a good deal of specula tion as to who will l»e Sir Vincent's successor. Some say that Mr. Fantail is a likely candidate. This opinion is evidently founded on the impression that, as Sir Vincent Corbett became Financial Adviser after having been British Commissioner on the Caisse de la Dette, therefore the present holder of that post will succeed. But this gentleman has a very short acquaintance with Egypt ami although he is recognised as a sort of polymath from the Foreign Office and has served on numberless conferences and conventions and is a very well informed person, his acquaintance with finance is not considerable. The same objection may be raised against Lord Edward Cecils chances. Among the higher Anglo-Egyptian officials there are few more popular men than he, for he is recognised as a capable representative of one of the ablest English families and is entirely destitute of that pretentiousness, which frequently characterises Apglo Egyptian officials, especially those of the lower middle class. Bat his training from the time he entered the Grenadier Guards in 1887 has been military and administrative ami he has had no acquaintance with the intricacies of finance. Chitty Bey ought to be the favourite candidate. He has an intimate knowledge of the revenue departments, which he gained as Controller of Direct Taxes ami Director General of Customs. His ability is incontestable ami under the guidance of Sir Eldon Gorst there is no reason that he should not be able to fulfil the duties of his high position. As Lord Milner pointed out the position of a man having a veto on any finan cial measure is very nearly that of the Tribune of the people in ancient Rome, who had a veto on everything ;and a man who has a veto on everything is master of the situation. When, moreover, the person who is already master of the situation by virtue of his functions, also happens to be a citizen of the State which is in military occupation of the country, the magnitude of his powers is obvious. Sir Auckland Colvin, the first occupant of the office, and his successor, Sir Edgar Vincent, were both strong men and the great essential in such a |K>st is strength, which quality eminently forms part of Chitty Bey's character It is impossible to foretell who will be the new Financial Adviser, but there can he no doubt about Chitty Bey having better qualifications for the position than any other Anglo-Egyptian official.

div.head: M. DE RUSTAEJAELL'S COPTIC MSS.
div.p: The following letter appears in the "Times": Sir,—I have seen many references in tho newspapers to the MSS. sent home by me from Egypt, and shall be indebted to you if you will permit me to make the following statement.

I secured the MSS. in the hope of rendering a public service. They seemed to me to possess the greatest interest for all denominations of the Christian Church. A further scanization by M. Lacan, the well known Coptic scholar of the Institute Franyais at Cairo, confirmed this view. He proved that many of the MSS., and in particular the Nubian volume, were unique, and tho others of considerable historical value.

The only 13 leaves hitherto known Of the Coptic version of the apocryphal Sayings of Christ—12 at Paris and one at Berlin—were published by M. Lacau in 1904 in the "M£-moires par les Membres de ITnstitut Franyais d'Arch^ologie Orientale du Caire," Vol. IX.
The MSS. in my possession have not been translated yet.
Yours faithfully, R. DE RuSTAFJAELL.
Junior Athemeum Club, 116, Piccadilly, W., July 24.

div.head: FIANCIAL CRISIS.
THE CRISIS AND THE COTTON TRADE.
div.p: 'I'o THE Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Dear, Sir,—Your recent issues have contained some very interesting articles with reference to the financial crisis in Egypt and the consequences resulting therefrom to the export and import trade. One of these under the heading of "The Crisis and the cotton crop" appearing in your issue of tho 19th. inst, contains much valuable information on the subject, but at the same time the writer is evidently not quite conversant with the present situation of export trade and cotton buying in the interior. First of all, it is by no means the spinner that finances the Egyptian cotton crop ; quite on the contrary, the parts have been reversed, and virtually it is now a-days the export merchant, who has become the spinners stock-keeper and banker. Export merchants are obliged to sell the cotton to spinners for near or distant shipments, according to the requirements of the mills, contracts having been already made with many mills for monthly shipments up to September 1908. The spinner is only financing his purchases from date of shipment, but the whole of the financing, from the plant or from the cultivators' stores, during transport to ginning factories, during ginning process, during transport to Alexandria and, last but not least, during the interval from arrival in Alexandria and the shipping dates, has to be done by merchants in Egypt. The financing up to arrival in Alexandria is done either by merchants reselling the cotton here, or by export merchants having their own buying agencies spread over the country, the latter being in the proportion of probably 40% of the whole crop.

If one considers that this quantity of seed cot t<m at the present level of prices corresponds to an outlay of at least 12 million pounds sterling, it is needless to remark that the few large export firms, who are doing the bulk of their own buying in the interior, will require considerable assistance from European and local hanks for this huge task. Still more peihaps the assistance of local banks and bankers is required by the large class of merchants buying from cultivators and reselling in Alexandria to the export trade. Finally, even those export merchants, who are not organized for buying direct from cultivators, require the assistance of local and European bank's for converting, during the early part of the season, their paper covering future contracts, into actual cotton, as they cannot, of course, run the risk of waiting until the dates of shipments arranged with the mills, as otherwise they might not get the required qualities, or at least might have to pay exorbitant premiums over contracts for certain qualities or special kinds, which have become scarce or are being oversold (I recall the exorbitant prices of Joanovich and Abbassi, ami to a certain extent the better qualities of Mitafifi this season).

If it may be assumed that the cotton export merchants buying in the interior have not .suffered in a direct manner by the financial crisis to any considerable extent, the same, perhaps, is not the case with many of the large class of merchants trading between the interior and Alexandria, and I am afraid that many of them are not for the moment in a position to assist materially in the financing of the cotton crop movement. Now, with regard to the capital of shippers, which the writer of the article of the 19th of July supposes to he mostly free at this time of the year, this may he the case with those shippers buying exclu sively or mostly in Alexandria, and covering their sales during summer with future contracts at the Bourse. In this case they even cashed important differences of prices from their contract sellers, because a large proportion of sales to the mills was made when November contracts were between §18 and 20.—and only a smaller quantity at higher rates. On the contrary, those shippers who have their own buying agencies in the interior have covered most of their sales to the mills in the interior, and, if I may be allowed to make a guess at the total quantity bought in the interior by shippers up to date, I should name one million canters as a probable figure, this meaning an outlay of about £1,000,000 in the form of advances on those purchases to cultivators. (Other 500,000 can tars may have been bought by merchants trading between the Interior and Alexandria).

Of course the buyers of this cotton (and of the remainder of the crop later on) will require, its they do every year, the assistance of foreign and local banks, and if this should be witheld from them or remain much below what it used to be in other years, the movement of the crop would certainly be hindered considerably. It is quite certain that the consequences would have to be sustained by the cultivators, as is the case now with cereals, the prices of which were from P T. 130-140 before the crisis, and have been depressed to P.T. 95 or in some cases even P.T. 90. On the other hand it is true that cultivators have obtained during the last few years such highly remunerative prices that with the exception of those woo paid exorbitant prices, for recent land acquisitions or who are indebted too much in comparison with their yearly income, they can easily sustain a certain decline. If in former years, and especially last season, they often obtained for their cotton much more than its market value from small merchanfs speculating on a future advance, they will, probably, see this coming season the reverse of the medal, and be obliged to go in search of buyers, without sometimes being able to find them even materially below Alexandria market value, because most merchants will be obliged to limit their purchases to their nearer shipping requirements, unless they obtain the customary assistance from local banks.
I am, Dear Sir, Suum Cuique Alexandria, 31st. July.

div.head: PORTS AND LIGHTHOUSES ADMINISTRATION.
CHARGE AGAINST INSPECTOR.
div.p: A Council of Discipline met this rooming at the Port and Lighthouses Administration in order to enquire into the charges brought against Bimbashi Mohamed Effendi Safouat, Inspector of the Quays at Alexandria, and his subordinate. Gedge Pasha, acting Director General of the Administration, Dixon Bey and Kamal Bey, representing the Ministry of Finance, are attending the Council.

In reference to the scandals in the Porte and Lighthouses Administration it is worthy of note that the post of Inspector of the Quays is the only responsible post in this Administration given to a native.

In reference to the question of the retirement of Rear Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield frotn the Director Generalship of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration, we understand that it was Sir Massie's intention to retire as soon as the new Pass was completed and opened.
A contemporary remarks as follows:—

Des scandales ont dclatd a Uadministration des Porte et Phares, les coupables vont etre jug^.s et ce sera d'un salutaire example. Mais une affaire de concussion n'est pas encore terming que d£j& l'on pressent qne la lists n'est pas pr£s d'etre close. M. Dixon bey, le sous-directenr financier de l'administration des Porte et Phares a fait son devoir, il le fera encore a i'avenir et dans toutes les occasions, il faut espgrer qu'il arrivera a faire disparaltre cette tare qu'est le bakchiche parmi les employes qu il a sous ses ordres. Pour amener ce rdsultat, on seroble $tre decide a prendre des mesures radicales. On va reorganiser le service du contrOle qui etait auparavant tout-a-fait insuthsant.

A la su te des faits qui viennent de se pro-duire, il est a peu pr£s certain que le contre-amiral Sir Massie R. Blomfield demanderait, & son retour de conge, d'etre admis a faire valoir ses droits a la retraite, non pas qu'il puisse etre rendu responsable en quoi que ce soitdesre-cente scandales qui out edate dans 1'adminis-tration quil dirige, mais son grand Age lui commando de prendre un repos bien gagne et la reorganisation des services qui va avoir lieu imposeraitau vieillard une fatigue qu'il nepeut plus supporter. Cependant le gouverneinent, d^sireux de reconnaltre les prdcieux services rondus parl'amiral Blom field, tr^s prohablenient lui accordera la pension entire.

These inferences are not correct. Sir Massie Blomfield remained in the Administration for the past two years in order to see the new pass carried through, and if he does retire shortly it will be in consequence of this work having Veen completed, and not as a result of the recent revelations Jnto certain irregularities among the minor officials in the administration.

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM.
A NEW DEPARTURE
(FROM "AL WATAN.")
div.p: The Nationalist of Egypt is a curious being, an exception to the rule of nature under which bodies are known to he hot in summer and cold in winter. He emits all his heat in winter and cools down in summer. The last utterances of the two Nationalist journalists who are now in London are strangely moderate and cool as compared with the hot and extreme vapourings of last winter in "Al-Moayad" and other Nationalist papers. These newspapers had carried the campaign against England too far. They had published every thing likely to create hatred and avowed enmity to England. They had insisted upon an Egyptian Parliament and complete independence, refusing to hear of half measures or compromise. They had steadily and obstinately kept the name of Denishwaibefore the public because its memory excited tho worst emotions and added to the growing hatred of the Egyptians to Englishmen and foreigners in general. They instructed their friends at the General Assembly to ask for the complete control of the finan cesand policy of the country. In a word, our Nationalists were too hot and extreme in winter, rivalling in the variety of their hos tilities. Now that we are in the hot season, these rabid enemies of England have apparently lost all their heat. Two of them are in London asserting their friendship to England and her people, declaring that they wish the British rule to last. They have no desire to claim control over the policy and finances of their country. Apparently they willingly leave all this to England and do not mean to worry over the question of an Egyptian Parliament. They even boast of their "moderation" and claim to be against the extreme tone of "Al-Lewa." So great has the change been that "Al-Minbar" has abruptly stopped the publication of verse and prose about Denshwai, and all matters antiEnglish have been eliminated from the two newspapers whose editors are now enjoying the welcome and horfpitelity of that most unnatural growth in modern politics, the Socialist members of the House of Commons.

We are glad to note this change, and we hope that the present "moderation" will last through many summers and winters. In their summer cooling these Nationalists come round to our own way of thinking, although they are far from admitting such facte. Meanwhile, the glory of permanent heat in tho Nationalist camp is entirely left to "Al-Lewa."

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limites- free discussion.

div.head: LOST CHAMPIONSHIPS.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Dear Sir,—I have just read your leader of yesterday on "Lost Championships/' and whilst deprecating strongly the tendency one sees at home in England towards slackness in some of our youth, I cannot as one who follows keenly athletics of all kinds, allow to pass without dissent the wailing'note of the quotation from the "Daily Telegraph."

In nearly all athletic contests requiring staying power and stamina, the Old Country still holds her own well, or if Britishers do not hold the championships in several cases onr Colonies do ip. the person of men of British descent
Shrubb and some of our others are still far and away the best long distance runners.
The Diamond Sculls, (the blue ribbon of the amateur sculling world) are still and always have been held by an Englishman though open to all comers.
The world, champion swimmer though an Australian is a Colonist of British descent, as is also the lawn tennis champion (men's singles).

True the Grand Challenge Cup at Henley was won by the Belgians, but that by no means gives them the rowing championship. Their crew saved themselves for and only rowed in the one race, whilst several membera of the English crews competed in other events, so that while giving the Belgians every credit for their win, in the most sportsmanlike manner, it is very far from the fact to say that they hold the champion honours.
Polejumping mentioned in the 'D. T's' list, one hardly ever sees in England, so it is misleading to quote it.

Again, more yacht races I venture to say, are sailed bjF British and Colonial boats and won, than by all other nationalities put together, soagain the"D.T."is rather over the mark in awarding yachting championships to America and Germany.

It is well known amongst yachting men that if the British boats which competed in the Anglo American International Race, could be built where they are sailed as* the Yankee boats are, the conditions would be very different.
Yours truly, H. W.
Alexandria 31st July 1907.
CRIME IN THE BEHERA.
(Translated from the Italian).
To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazettb."

Sir,--1 have seen the various letters in your journal on the subject of the terrible state of affairs existing in the province of the Behera I may inform you of the following incident, which possibly will enlighten your readers and the Ministry of the Interior on the real condition of things there. Some time ago an important land development company had an employ6 murdered. The Company at once applied to the authorities A few days afterwards they sent an official of the Pdhjuet to hold an enquiry on the matter. Soon afterwards a young Englishman went down. He was beautifully dressed in breeches and a helmet. He also held an enquiry. Then the matter stopped. Some days elapsed and nothing was done. The consequence was that a week after the murder the actual assassin was killed. Since that date the company has not been troubled by any other case.
Yours, etc.
G. I.
Alexandria, August 1st 1907.
EGYPTIAN TRADE DIFFICULTIES.
The "Financial Times" in its banking notes remarks: *

The troubles regarding Egyptian bills have been a little larger than is generally understood/ for we learn that the paper of one important Egyptian firm in question ran into nearly three-quarters of a million. Fortunately, however, the matter was in strong hands from thebeginning, and the preliminary investigation on the part of those primarily interested led to the conclusion that there was fair scope for allowing some grace to those who were unable tn meet payments at the exact date. Accordingly a kind of committee has been formed, which will look alter the matter from the European standpoint, and although such arrangements are not liked by the market as a rule, there is little question that in this case good will be done by the decision arrived at. At the same time it will not wholly remove the diffi culties of the position, for naturally Egyptian paper will not lie so readily accepted as before, and next autumn this circumstance pay lead to a littfe trouble in Egypt when the excellent cotton crop which is expected to be^gathered will have to be handled.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: It is rumoured that Ismail Pasha Sirri* Inspector Gerieral ofthe Projects Circle, is to succeed Fakhry Pasha on his retireinent from the Portfolio of Public Works.
M. de Reffye, French Consul at Cairo who has been spending several days at Alexandria* has returned to Cairo. He is expected to sail next Friday for France.
M. Chevandier de Valdtome of the Ptenoh Agency, who has been since Friday last'at Iamailieh, has returned to Cairo in cotapaoy with Count de Sdtionne. He arrived yesterday afternoon at San Stefano.
Dr. Garner, chief sanitary inspector, has returned from his vacation, and will replace Sir Horace Pinching, who is leaving next week for Europe.

We regret to learn that Mr. Dalby, of the Cairo School for the deaf and dumb, is lying in so precarious a condition, as the result of an accident which he sustained while trying to mount a tram in motion, that his life is despaired of.
Mr. and Mrs. F. W. Skeates have left by the S.S. "Irrawady" for England.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
CRICKET.
div.p: ALEXANDRIA v. RAMLEH.

On Tuesday afternoon a cricket match was played between teams representing Alexandria and Ramleh which * resulted in an easy win for the former. Ramleh batted first and H. B. Carver soon got "set." By excellent play all round the wicket he totalled 101, but unfortunately no member of the team could second him. Some good bowling was seen by Dawson, whose 9 overs included five^ maidens arid fiye wickets fell to him for 18 runs. Barnard, who took the ball towards the close Of the innings, was also very successful, his analysis being 3 overs, 10 runs, 3 wickets. The batting of the Alexandria team wassteady with brilliant play by Hay and Prosser who put together 58 and 57, respectively. Barnard compiled 45 in very neat style and useful contributions were made by Dawson of 35 and Mainprioe 22.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujour@ hui @ 11h, 1/2 am).

La fatigue que nous avions signaHe bier en dypit d'une hansse apparente s'est fait jour ce matin. Toute la cote a ouvert en dypression marqnye, pour se relever un peu, il est vrai, vers la fin ; mais on n'en clOtare pas moins A un niveau gdndralement infyrieur A celui d'hier. Les affaires ont perdu en nombre et en importance; de plus, elles sesont limityes k une certainc categoric de valeurs. Le motif de cette reaction est vraisemblablement celui que nous avons exposy dans nos prycydents bulletins: outre les revirements inyvitables qui accom-pagnent toujours les mouvements A la hausse, il y a sans doute aussi la rentrye en sc£ne du dycouvert. En ce qui concerne la situation financi^re, il est difficile de la mettre en avant, attendu qu'il n'ya rien de changy jusqu'ici.

A commencer par les valeurs dirigeantes, elles sent toutes en baisse : l'Agricole flychit de 8 3/16 A 8 1/16 avec un chiffre d'affaires excessivement restreint; la National Bank, un peu 'plus echangye, recule egalement de 20 A 19 7 8, ainsi que la Delta Light de 10 A 9 7/8, et l'Obligation Crydit Foncier de 306 A 304 l'ancienne et de 263 1/2 a 262 vendeurs la non-velle. Quant a la Daira, elle s'inscrit a 12 7/8 vendeurs ex-coupon, contre 14 1/4 hier.
En baisse encore les Jouissances Earn du Caire de 186 A 182, laByhyra de 20 1/4 A 20, les Sucreries de 40 A 35, la Land Bank de 7 1 /16 A 7, la Banque d'Orient de 116 1 /2 A 110-
Parmi les petites valeurs, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail revient de 22 acheteurs a 22 ven-denr?, l'lnvestment de 9/16 A 1/2, les Estates de 11/16 A 5/8, l'Aboukir de 30 A 29, l'United de 13/82 A 3/8.

Les Priviiygites Tramways d'Alexandrie fld-chissent de 138 A 137 1 2, tandis que les Dividendes reprennent de 285 a 290; de m£me Faction Comptoir perd 1/16 A 2 11/16 l'ancienne et 2 5/8 la nouvelle, tandis que la part de fondateur gagne 3/8 A 3.
Les Markets s'avancent de 26/9 A 27 6,1$ Banqued'AtMnes de 110 A 111, la Building Lauds de 2 3/8 A 2 7/16, et la Zariffa de 3 A 3 1/8;sa part de fondateur s'inscrit A 4.

Bien que l'information suivant laquelle les titres de la Bourse and Banking (Arditi) seraient livres A partir de 8 courant soit offi-cielle, il en est qui continuent A se montrer sceptiques relativement A cette livraison. Toujours est-il qne le comity de l'Association des courtiers en valeurs d'Alexandrie informe les mernbres de cette association que la liquidation relative aux transactions sur la Bourse and Banking est terminye sur les bases de la d<Mi-byration prise par l'Assemblyedu 15 juillet.

Lemarchy de Londres concernant des valeurs ygyptiennes nous est arrivy un peu plus faible, et e'est pent-ytre A ce motif qu'il faut, en partie du moins, attribuer la faction que nous avons signake au commencement de ce bulletin. En outre, constatation plotOt d6fa-vorable, le tanx privy d'escompte s'avance A 3 3/4 en m^me temps que le Consolidy flychit. La rente franchise perd aussi quelques points.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
REGLEMENT CONCERNANT LES CONSTRUCTIONS.
div.p: Le President de la Commission Municipale,
Vu Part 15, paragraphe8 du D^cret du 5 janvier 1890 instituant la Commission Municipale d'Alexandrie ;
Vu la deliberation de cette Commission en date du 3 juillet 1907 approuv6e parS.E. le Ministre de l'lnterieur ;
ARRETE : Article Premier.

Les mesures et prescriptions suivantes seront appliqu^es a titre tiansitoire en attendant la promulgation d'un rdglement definitif concernant las routes ainsi que le contrOle des constructions dans la ville d'Alexandrie :

Nul ne pourra constrnire, agrandir, surgever, reconforter ou Sparer dans le perim&tre de la ville d'Alexandrie, & qnelque titre ou dans qnelque limiteque ce soit, des maisons, Edifices, murs de clAture, balcons, perrons, trottoirs, ou tout ouvrage avant que les plans de l'ouvrage projet^ ne soient soumis h la Municipality et approuv&s par elle et avant d'avoir re<;u du Service du Tanzim I'autorisa-tion de l'alignement en ce qui concerne les ouvrages bordant la voie publique.
Les dessins & presenter en double expedition par les intlressds devront comprendre :
а) Les plans du rez de-chaussde et des divers dtages avec elevations et coupes a I'echelle de 1/100.
б) Un plan d'ensemble de I'emplacemeut a construire, des voies qui le bordent ou l'avoi-sinent ainsi que des dispositions de drainage ^I'echelle de 1/1000.

c) Les plans des solivages et toitures a l'e-chellede 1/100 avec disposition descheminees avec details cotes a I'echelle de 1/10 des soli-ves ou poutrelles (leur section et espacement d'axe en axe) ou de tout autre systfcme employer.
d) Des details cot 5s k I'echelle de 1/10 de toutes autres parties essentielles de construction, (piliers, colonnes, consoles et sections des fondations).
Les interesse.s auront en outre a soumettre a la Municipality le cahier aux travaux a executer.

L'Administration devra, quinze joins apartirde la dessins et cahier des charges ci-dessus, mani-fester son approbation et deiivrer en consequence la rokhsa de construction et d'aligne-ment. Au cas oil ces dessins et cahier des charges n'auraient pas ety agrees, la Municipality devra dans le meme delai en faire part aux interesses et leur communiquer les observations quelle croira devoir formuler.
Aucune modification au plan approuve par la Municipality ou au cahier des charges ne pourra etre apportee sans 1'agrement ecrit de cette derniere.

Les agents preposes an controle des cons tructions auront libre acc£s 5 tout moment aux ouvrages et constateront toute inobservation des plans approuv£s ou du cahier des charges et dresseront les proces-verbaux y re-latifB dans les formes et avec les mGme^ sanctions adoptees en mati&re de contravention au regiement du Tanzim.
La Municipality pourra retirer dans ce cas l'autorisation et empAcher toute continuation des travaux.

L'autorisation donnle par la Municipalite pas plus que l'approbation dos plans et cahier des charges ou le contrdle exerce par ses agents, n'implique pour elle aucune respon-sabilite, laquelle demeure pleine et entire a la charge des interesses
Art. 2.
I^e present arret*, qui ne deroge pas aux Lois et Ryglemente existants, entrera en gueur trente jours apr^s sa publication Journal Offieiel.
Fait a Alexandrie, le 8 juillet 1907.
Publie au Journal Offieiel du 24 juillet 1907, N°85.

div.head:
RAID ON CASABLANCA.
CRUISER TO THE RESCUE.
EIGHT EUROPEANS KILLED.

div.p: 'Hires tribes have raided Casablanca, resenting the construction of harbour works and tramways. They have massacred a number of workmen. It is stated that 5 Frenchmen, 2 Italians and a Spaniard have been killed. A German ship has brought the snrvivors here. (Reuter)

The French cruiser "Galilee has left for Casablanca. The townspeople perpetrated the murders, headed by tribesmen, near a qnarry from where the locomotive wa9 returning to the harbour. The native fireman first stabbed the driver who was cut to pieces. The bashaw and the troops practically abetted the murderers. (Reuter)
The representatives of Franco has received the condolences of the various Powers.
The cruiser "Galilee" will harbour the foreigners. (Havas)
The French and foreign journals unite in demanding the punishment of the authors of the Casablanca massacres. (Havas)
Two cruisers are sailing tor Morocco. (Havas)

div.head:
ROYAL IRISH CONSTABULARY
PRECAUTIONS AGAINST MUTINY.

div.p: The presence of the military here is precautionary in view of the possible strike of the Constabulary when the disaffected men meet to receive the answer to their grievances from Headquarters. 4 battleships and 2 cruisers have arrived in the Lough but the visit was arranged long ago. from the police in pour into Belfast.
Messages of sympathy other districts continue to (Renin)
Barrett, the ringleader of has been dismissed. The

The policeman the disturbances, Lord Lieutenant has issued an order refusing to consider the petition of the discontented men because it was presented under condition of insubordination and threats. (Reuter)

div.head:
COLONEL ELLIOT WOUNDED.
ATTCACKED BY BULGARIANS.

div.p: A party of Bulgarians have wounded Colonel Elliot while on his way to Nevrokof. (Havas)
House of Commons.— the Navy Estimates have been adopted. The Radical motion for reduction has been rejected by 263 votes to 86. (Reuter)
Prince von Buelow is leaving for Swine-munde, where the interview between the Tsar and the Emperor will shortly be held. //.
The Japanese have disbanded the Korean tuny. 40 Koreans have been killed or wounded in the riots following the disarmament. (R.)
Prince Borghese has arrived. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE HAGUE CONFERNECE.
"ENDLESS TALK.
BRITISH CONTRABAND PROPOSAL.

div.p: There is endless talk at the Conference but nothing is done. The commission has adopted the British proposal to abolish contraband but the minority includes America, Germany, Russia and France. The impossibility of reconciling all views prevents progress in every subject.

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LIGHT RAILWAYS, LTD.
MARKED IMPROVEMENT IN PASSENGERTRAFFIC REPROTED.
div.p: The annual ordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Egyptian Delta Light Railway, Ltd., was held last week at Win Chester House, Old Broad street, E. C. The Hon. Sir Charles William Fremantle, K. C. B. (Deputy-Chairman of the company), presided.
The Secretary (Mr. F. J. Horne) having read the notice convening the meeting and the report of the auditors.

The ('hairman said : Gentlemen,—I have, with much regret, to inform you that our Chairman, Sir Auckland Colvin, is prevented by illness from being in his place at this meeting. Before proceeding to a review of the accounts, 1 should like to remove from your minds any concern you may have felt at the recent low prices at which onr preference shares have stood. You will have observed from the accounts that for the first time in the history of this company we are able to recommend a distribution of the full 5J per cent, per annum on these shares. Our earnings for the fourteen weeks from the 1st April last are £11,861, or 20 per cent, ahead of those ot the same period of the year under review, and, so far as 1 know or can foresee, the prospects of our undertaking were never more bright than at present The fact is that Egypt, in my opinion, continues to make steady progress, but over-speculation has been going on there for some years, and the inevitable result has happened. Stocks and shares, with hardly an exception, had become inflated yi value, and when realisation pecaine necessary it was proved how fictitious many of these values were. A regular panic arose on this discovery, and the whole list of securities was pressed for sale. Our shares, with others equally good, had to be sacrificed, and went down with the rest.. I can only tell you that, so far as I am aware, ^io official connected with this company has parted with a single share. In regard to the accounts with which we have to deal to-day, I would remind you that those presented to you on the last occasion were for halt a year only ; this was due to the change made in our financial year. We are now able to return to a full year, and, for present purposes of comparison, have taken the previous twelve months ; in other words, the six months, which were separately accounted for on the last occasion of our meeting together, and six months of the year ended 30th September, 1905. We have also got the accounts of the Helouan branch on the same lines as the rest of our undertaking, which has simplified matters and improved financial control considerably. There are, and probably must be, during the remainder of the existing concession of the Helouan line, reasons for keeping its accounts separate,1 and, to some extent, the same reasons have led us to separate those of the recently-opened Cairo quarry lines, but I feel that., on an occasion like the present, our principal concern is with the combined figures of the whole of onr undertaking.

div.head: THE GROSS EARNINGS.
div.p: Our gross earnings increased over the corresponding period by £31,640, of which rather lass than half—namely, £15,350—was absorbed by increased expenses, the resulting net receipts from our working being £109,095, or 42.65 per cent, of our gross receipts, as against £92,808, or 41.41 per cent for the previous twelve months. In other words, they represented rather over 6 per cent on the share capital after payment of all fixed charges, which latter, as you are aware, not only include interest on debentures, but provision for redemption as well as for the redemption of the whole of our share capital, at the termination of our concession. The most marked improvement has again been in our passenger traffic, as reference to the report in your hands will have shown you, but a detailed analysis which I have been able to make shows that both the number of and receipts from passengers increased in every district which we serve, and I may mention that the receipts under this head for the first quarter of the current financial year—i.e., from April to June—show an improvement of about 25 per cent, over the corresponding months of the year under review. The increasing prosperity of the country accounts primarily for this, but the well directed attention of our management to the needs and difficulties of the position have secured to us the advantages therefrom. Our goods earnings have also progressed satisfactorily—namely, 9 J per cent, over the previous year—and you will have noticed that increases have occurred under all the important items of this traffic. I am able to tell you that these also have extended to all provinces and to traffic interchanged with the Egyptian State Railways. The total quantity of all goods handled by us was slightly less than in the previous twelve months, but this is no disturbing factor, for the diminution was in low class traffic, such as stones, earth and manure, which we have less inducement t-o seek for when better traffic offers. In my opinion this must continue to be the case, owing to the additional areas being brought under cultivation and the increased crops produced by the use of chemical manures and more scientific methods of agriculture. The effects upon our undertaking are that what may be called the slack time, during which we fall back upon anything that can pay any price at all for transport, is being greatly curtailed, and I find that on comparing our average rate for conveying a ton of goods a kilometre this has increased to P.T. 406 from P.T. 391 in the preceding twelve months. I am not going to occupy your time with details of the separate accounts, which are useful for purposes of control and necessary to us in effecting settlement with Government under our different contracts, but our study of these has shown us that on both the deltas proper and on the Helouan branch we have reason to be satisfied with our earnings, lioth passenger and goods, and I would further like to explain that, though I have referred to a diminution in our stone traffic, this has not extended to our quarry lines at Abouzaabal and El Mounir, on which the traffic has increased. It may be convenient fur me to mention here that our Cairo Quarry lines were sufficiently completed at the 1st. April to treat them as revenue-earning from that date, and their prospects are regarded as satisfactory, though they have been rather more expensive to construct than we had estimated.

div.head: WORKING EXPENSES.
div.p: I will now turn for a moment to our working expenses. Though I put it in a different form in on earlier partof my speech—namely, as the increased percentage of net to total earnings, yon probably gathered therefrom that our ratio of expenses to earnings has fallen from 58.59 in the previous twelve months to 57.35 in the year under review. I have also told you that the increase of £31,640 in our traffic has been worked for considerably less than 50 per cent. To be exact, the percentage is 4 i524. This you will, I am sure, consider satisfactory and creditable to our staff. But it is really more so than the figures show. The prosperity of the country, by which we have benefited so much, has in itself caused salaries and wages to rise against us, the cost of coal has been higher, and we have had to effect a lot of improvements at the cost of revenue. In some cases these have been to increase our station accommodation, in others to straighten curves in our roads, to improve our water-supply, &c., hut nearly, if hot all, are traceable to the same cause — namely, to the growth of our traffic and to the heavier trains we require to move it. 1 am afraid we still have much to face in several of these directions, but I see no reason why the net results should not prove increasingly satisfactory, as in the accounts which it has been my privilege to explain to you on this occasion. Our Chairman (Sir Auckland Colvin), went over portions of our lines, including the Cairo Quarry lines, which I have just referred to in the early part of the year, with our general manager (Captain Adams, R.E.), who we are happy to have*with us here to day, and our managing director made a more extended tour <>f them later. I am happy to tell you that both the Chairman's observations and the managing director's report were highly satisfactory, and our best thanks are duo to the general manager and his staff for their efficient conduct of our business. This efficiency is admiiably combined with strict regard to economy and exists under conditions both difficult and varied. During times of great prosperity and ite acconv panimente, such as have prevailed recently in Egypt, attractions present themselves to salaried officials, and though they may be neither real nor lasting, they are not easy to combat; again our working has to be conducted not only to the satisfaction of the company and of the public, but. to that of Government as well, and onr undertaking is a combination of agricultural lines in the districts and a fashionable suburban line out of Cairo. We have satisfactorily met all demands upon us, 1 but in the case of the Helouan line these are increasing to such an extent that we have decided to ask permission from Government to electrify it We have reason to believe that our application is being favourably considered. . The change will, if sanctioned, involve consi- 1 derable outlay, as it will include the cost ot taking up and relaying our present line, as i part of an extension southwards from Helouan, but we shall be compensated for this part of our undertaking. I may, however, explain that the extension of the Helouan line is in no way connected with the resolution to be put before you to-day, which only relates to modifications assented to by Government on our taking over this line from its previous owners.

div.head: CONSTRUCTION OF EXTENSIONS.
div.p: During the year under review our average kilometrage was only increased by about 2 per cent., but since its close a length of 22 kilometres of oor Cairo Quarry lines and of one of our northern extensions has been opened, and the rest of the latter has been surveyed, while the other of these extensions, some 80 kilometres in length, has been practically completed. The most important addition to our undertaking now contemplated is the extension of the Helouan branch, to which I have just referied. From Helouan the line will probably be extended southwards for about 60 kilometres, as a steam road, and would tap a tract of country adjacent to the Nile, and to the development of which considerable attention is being turned. It will depend to a great extent upon the decisions of the Government and this company in this matter what additions we may have to make to our capital, but I have here to mention that, in any case, we expect to make an issae of either shares ot debentures, towards the close of the current year, by which time we hope that good Egyptian securities will Rtand at better prices than they do now. Under existing financial circumstances, we have thought it better to borrow from the banks and from our reserve funds, than even to sell our unissued debentures. At the last general meeting of this company, the severance of the connection between it and the Egyptian Delta Ijanrt and Investment Company, and the reasons therefor, were described to you. For all practical purposes, such severance was then regarded as completed, and the consent of the Courts to certain alterations which required their sanction was looked upon as a mere formality: Such sanction was, however, subsequently and unexpectedly made conditional on the name of the Egyptian Delta I^and and Investment Company being so altered as to avoid misun-der standing as to a change having been made in ite sphere of operations. The Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company was not prepared thus to sacrifice its identity, aud consequently when all had been arranged, the matter was dropped and the reason for separating the t wo companies disappeared. Sir A uckland Colvin was in Egypt at that time,as Chairman of both the railways and the land companies, and the Boards there, of both companies, pressed him to return to the status quo ante. From careful inquiry on the spot, he found that the proposed separationof the two companies had never been received with favour in Egypt, and you will remember that he told you that we had reluctantly agreed to it here. Subject to the consent of your Board in London, your Chairman, therefore, agreed to return to the former position, and the Land Company consented to restore to us our former holding of their shares, for the net price at which we had disposed of them. We now, therefore, again hold our 20,000 shares in the Egyptian Delta I^and and Investment Company, the investment having been made from the share premium moneys. The only changes effected in the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company are that, that company now has its own manager and staff, and that its direction has been transferred to Egypt. The protection of the interests of our company is secured by four out of the seven directors of the land company being directors or officers of the railway company. I may mention that since the close of accounts under review, we have received from the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company a dividend of 15 per cent, upon our shares. (Applause.) If any shareholders desire any further information I shall be happy to supply it to the best of my ability. I now beg to move the following resolution: "That the report of the directors,dated the 4th July, 1907 together with the statement of accounts and balance-sheet for the year ended 81st March, 1907, be and they are hereby approved, confirmed and adopted."
Mr P. W. Carver seconded the motion, which was carried unanimously.
t The Chairman next moved :—"That the in-
- terim dividend paid on the preference share
capital of this company in December, 1906, at the rate of 4 per cent, per annum, for the half-
year ended 30th September, 1906, be confirmed,
- and that a dividend at the rate of 7 per cent.

per annum for the half year ended 31st March, 1907, on the preference share capital of the company be, and hereby is, declared to be paid to the holders of preference shares standing on the registers of the company at 16th July, 1907, and to the holders of preference share warrants to bearer."
Mr. Robert Miller seconded the resolution, which was agreed to.
The Chairman then proposed :—"That Sir Auckland Colvin, one of the directors retiring by rotation, be re-elected."
Major W. I. le Breton seconded, and the motion was carried.
The Chairman also moved :— "That Mr. Montagu Sharpe, one of the retiring directors, be re-elected."
This was seconded by Mr. Robert Miller and agreed to.
On the motion of the Chairman, seconded by Sir Francis L. O'Callaghan, Maurice Cattau i Bey, one of the retiring directors, was also reelected.

div.head: ELECTION OF AUDITORS
div.p: The Chairman : In asking a shareholder to propose the appointment of auditors to the company I beg to explain that the arrangement now extends to an auditor in Egypt as well as in London. For the latter Messrs. Meredith and Co., who are eligible for reelection, have received a fee of 50 guineas. Prom time to time an outside auditor has been deputed to conduct the audit in Alexandria, and for the year which we have jnst dealt with a member of Messrs. Meredith and Co.'s firm was selected. The arrangement has answered well, and it is desired to continue it This duty involvas the expenses of passages to and from Egypt, and of a stay there of three to four weeks. The inclusive fee, which we consider reasonable for this duty, is 200 guineas. The meeting will, on this occasion, be asked to provide for the two audits.

Mr. G. B. Cooper proposed :—"That Messrs. Meredith and Co. be elected auditors to the company for the ensuing year at an inclusive remuneration of 50 guineas for the London audit and 200 guineas for the audit in Egypt."
Mr. Prendegast seconded the resolution, which was unanimously agreed to.

The Chairman: Gentlemen, we now come to the resolution which is set out in the notice convening this meeting, and which, as I have already explained in my previous remarks, relates to the modifications of the Helouan concession assented to by Government on our taking over the Cairo-Helouan line from its previous owners. I now beg to more —"That the Board of Directors be authorised to enter into an agreement on behalf, of the company with the Egyptian Government, modifying the deed of concessions for the Helouan Railways and schedule of conditions, dated 30th April, 1888, in the form now submitted to the meeting and signed by the Chairman for the purposes of identification subject to any modifications or alterations to such agreement as the Board may deem desirable."
Mr. Montagu Sharpe seconded the resolution, which was unanimously carried.
A vote of thanks to the Chairman and directors closed the proceedings.
